ygData.subject: Mac OS X permissions issues
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all - I m having some trouble with Cantera on OS X 10.3.6. When running the python demos, I get the following error:

Hi all -

I'm having some trouble with Cantera on OS X 10.3.6. When running the python demos, I 
get the following error:
____________________________________________________________________
[/Applications/Cantera/demos/python] user% python flame1.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "flame1.py", line 44, in ?
    gas = IdealGasMix(rxnmech, mix)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.3/lib/python2.3/site-
packages/Cantera/gases.py", line 22, in IdealGasMix
    return Solution(src=src,id=id,loglevel=loglevel)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.3/lib/python2.3/site-
packages/Cantera/solution.py", line 38, in __init__
    root = XML.XML_Node(name = 'doc', src = src, preprocess = 1)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.3/lib/python2.3/site-
packages/Cantera/XML.py", line 35, in __init__
    self._xml_id = _cantera.xml_get_XML_File(src)
cantera.error: 

************************************************
                Cantera Error!                  
************************************************


Procedure: ct2ctml
Error:   cannot open ./.cttmp1100971050.pyw for writing.
______________________________________________________________

This error is resolved when I type:
[/Applications/Cantera/demos/python] user% sudo python flame1.py 

While this is fine for Cantera in python in a terminal, I get the same error in Matlab and in 
Python IDE.

I think the main issue is the directory location for Cantera. When using the OSX installer 
from sourceforge, I don't think it uses the writeable /usr/local location, whereas an install 
from the source code does. Is the source code install the currently
better approach for OS X? Or should I just change a few permissions and environment 
variables to fix the current problem?

I think I have the right Python, MacPython, and Numpy parts installed (though that has 
been challenging too).

Thanks for any help here!

Josh Freeh
